Detailed Description

Applying convolution matrices to frames, separable or arbitrary.

Function Documentation

const int *  h,
int  h_len,
const int *  v,
int  v_len
) 
 

Parameters:
frame The frame.
h The horizontal part of the separable convolution matrix.
h_len The length of the horizontal part.
v The vertical part of the separable convolution matrix.
v_len The length of the vertical part.
Returns:
The resulting frame.
Applies a separable convolution matrix on a frame.

const int *  kernel,
int  dim_y,

) 
 

Parameters:
frame The frame.
kernel The convolution kernel as an array of ints.
dim_y Number of rows of the kernel.
dim_x Number of columns of the kernel.
Returns:
The resulting frame.
Applies a convolution kernel on a frame.

cvl_frame_t* cvl_frame_convolve3d_separable (  const cvl_frame_t *  frames[],
const int *  h,
int  h_len,
const int *  v,
int  v_len,
const int *  t,
int  t_len
) 
 

Parameters:
frames The frames.
h The horizontal part of the separable convolution kernel.
h_len The length of the horizontal part.
v The vertical part of the separable convolution kernel.
v_len The length of the vertical part.
t The temporal part of the separable convolution matrix.
t_len The length of the temporal part.
Returns:
The resulting frame.
Applies a separable 3D convolution matrix on a frame. The number of frames in the array frames must be t_len. Only the entry at (t_len / 2) must be non-NULL, because this is the frame that will be processed. The number of past and future frames (those with indices less than or greater than t_len / 2) can be limited; in this case, some array entries can be NULL. This function will use reflective indexing to compensate that.

cvl_frame_t* cvl_frame_convolve3d (  const cvl_frame_t *  frames[],
const int *  kernel,
int  dim_t,
int  dim_y,
int  dim_x
) 
 

Parameters:
frames The frames.
kernel The convolution kernel as an array of ints.
dim_t Dimension in temporal direction.
dim_y Dimension in vertical direction.
dim_x Dimension in horizontal direction.
Returns:
The resulting frame.
Applies a 3D convolution matrix on a frame. The number of frames in the array frames must be mt_len. Only the entry at (mt_len / 2) must be non-NULL, because this is the frame that will be processed. The number of past and future frames (those with indices less than or greater than mt_len / 2) can be limited; in this case, some array entries can be NULL. This function will use reflective indexing to compensate that.
